Comment: The new Pope plays Wordle, the Scrabble-like mobile game Words With Friends, and watched the movieÂ *Conclave*Â shortly before entering the real-life meeting that would elevate him to the Catholic Churchâ€™s highest office.  We know all of this thanks to anÂ [interview](https://www.nbcchicago.com/news/sports/mlb/chicago-cubs/got-it-wrong-brother-sets-record-straight-on-whether-new-pope-is-a-cubs-or-sox-fan/3741532/)Â with Pope Leo XIVâ€™s brother in Chicago, Illinois, after he became the worldâ€™s first American pontiff. But we also know one more thing about the new Pope: he has been an opinionated user of social media.Â   In previous ages, interpreting the political messaging of the pope was an art in itself, left to Vatican watchers with decades of experience in deciphering the subtle meanings of particular forms of words, the taking of a particular papal name, or the symbology of using or rejecting particular vestments.  With Pope Leo XIV, who before his elevation was Cardinal Robert Prevost, there is little need to resort to such measures. Through what he has shared on X, the Elon Musk-owned social network formerly known as Twitter, we have a direct idea of his views on US politics, and theÂ [policies of Donald Trumpâ€™s administration](https://inews.co.uk/opinion/trumps-critics-could-very-soon-look-like-chumps-3673093?ico=in-line_link).  As a cardinal, Prevost shared articles critical of Trumpâ€™s policy of family separation and detaining children at the border during his first term. More recently, he shared an article rebuking the President over his meeting with El Salvadorâ€™s president Nayib Bukele, who is administrating the overseas prisons to which Trump was unlawfully deporting migrants.  The posts are perhaps most embarrassing of all toÂ [Vice President JD Vance](https://inews.co.uk/opinion/jd-vance-disposable-mike-pence-3648160?ico=in-line_link), who converted to Catholicism in 2019 and who has publicly made much of his faith. Vanceâ€™s visit to the VaticanÂ [was widely interpreted as a snub from Pope Francis](https://inews.co.uk/news/after-meeting-jd-vance-pope-delivered-pointed-message-world-3651427?ico=in-line_link), who initially passed off the substantive meeting to his deputy, before very briefly meeting Vance on Easter Sunday,Â just hours before his death.

Comment: Vance has publicly offered a theological, Catholic, justification for Trumpism and its â€œAmerica Firstâ€ policies â€“ citing a principle of â€œordo amorisâ€, or â€œorder of loveâ€, essentially claiming Christianity teaches us to put our families first, then others around us, in concentric circles eventually ending with strangers.  Pope Francis publicly rejected that understanding of Catholicism, and in his previous social media posts, Pope Leo XIV did the same. Catholic doctrine holds that the pope is infallible when it comes to matters of theology (though not on broader political issues). JD Vance, a Catholic convert, hasÂ now been publicly contradicted by not one, but two, popes. To most Catholics, this would be an absolutely unendurable humiliation.  Magaworld, though, is somewhat divided on how to handle the first American Pope. Donald Trump clearly wants to claim Leo XIVâ€™s elevation as a win, and has hailed it as such â€“ and it is a bold man in Trump world who snatches a victory away from him.  But though Maga is more often associated with evangelical Christianity, it is surprisingly Catholic: five of the six conservative Supreme Court justices are Catholic, as is Steve Bannon, though the thrice-divorced architectÂ of Trumpâ€™s first victory referred to Francis as a â€œfalse popeâ€. Maga Catholicism is increasingly divorced from the economically Left-wing global Catholic Church â€“ and its influencers are already trying to dismiss Leo XIV as a â€œwoke popeâ€ (per influencer Laura Loomer, whoÂ [claims](https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/national-security/national-security-agency-chief-deputy-director-dismissed-rcna199647)Â she convinced Trump to sack several senior intelligence chiefs) or even as a plot against Trump or Magaworld.

Comment: Converts are always an odd bunch. Converts will never have the culture ingrained into them, the way those of us raised Catholic do. Even adult lapsed Catholics, like myself, have more intuitive understanding of the reality of the Catholic Church than converts. Converts actively chose the church because it appealed to their already held sensibilities/morals/world view. As a result, they donâ€™t understand the nuances of being from a deep-rooted culturally Catholic community and family. My extremely devout Catholic grandmother grew up in the Depression in a farm in North Dakota with a dozen siblings. She was a big denouncer of Trump and MAGA, and was a left of center Democrat. Her real life experiences that she or family members had involved abortions, miscarriages, immigration, interracial/intercultural marriages, queer people, poverty and hunger, depending on social programs, domestic violence, untimely tragic deaths, being small business owners, and on and on. The Catholic Church was a community that provided support and guidelines, but there was always the understanding that the rules arenâ€™t strict rules (thatâ€™s why Confession is a holy sacrament in the Church) and that decisions in life are not always going to be cut and dry.  All this is to say that Vance might be a more devout Catholic than I am currently, but heâ€™ll never grasp the culture of being Catholic authentically.

My grandparents were depression era first generation Americans with German catholic roots. They spent a lot of time supporting charity. For everyone and anyone. Black folks, even queer folks! My grandfather did this until his death in 2005.   JD Vance converted to make himself feel more legitimate.
